text: Ŋ (lowercase: ŋ) is a letter in the International Phonetic Alphabet. It is a letter in the Latin alphabet It is used to represent a sound in many languages. == Sound == The sound of Ŋ is called a voiced velar nasal. It is the same sound as the “ng” in the English word “sing.”Robert W. Albright (1958). The International Phonetic Alphabet: Its Backgrounds and Development, Indiana University. p. 11 == Usage == Many languages use the letter ŋ in their alphabets. Some examples include English. The letter is not used in usual English spelling, but the sound is common. For example, in “sing,” “long,” and “song.” A group of languages spoken by the Sami people in Northern Europe. Inuit: Languages spoken by the Inuit people in the Arctic regions of Greenland, Canada, and Alaska. Several African languages, such as Wolof and Bambara, use the letter ŋ. == Appearance == When it is uppercase, it looks like Ŋ. When the letter is lowercase, it looks like ŋ. The lowercase letter looks like an “n” with a long right leg that goes to the left. == History == The letter ŋ was first used in the 19th century by Danish Linguist Rasmus Rask. It was later put into the International Phonetic Alphabet to show the voiced velar nasal sound == References == Category:Latin letters with diacritics
title: Ŋ (letter)
